column1: Lynnwood is a city in Snohomish County
column3: United States. The city is part of the Seattle metropolitan area and is located 16 miles (26 km) north of Seattle and 13 miles (21 km) south of Everett
column4: near the junction of Interstate 5 and Interstate 405. It is the fourth-largest city in Snohomish County
column6: 836 in the 2010 U.S. census.

column1: Lynnwood is a suburban bedroom community for Seattle
column2: Everett and Bellevue. It has one of the largest concentrations of retailers in the region
column3: anchored by the Alderwood Mall and businesses along major streets. The city also has a community college
column6: located in the developing city center.

column1: The Lynnwood area was logged and settled by homesteaders in the late 19th century and early 20th century
column2: including the development of Alderwood Manor as a planned farming community. Lynnwood
column3: named for the wife of a realtor
column4: emerged in the late 1940s around the intersection of Highway 99 and 196th Street Southwest. The city was incorporated on April 23
column6: and grew into a suburban hub in the years following the completion of Interstate 5 and Interstate 405. Alderwood Mall opened in 1979 and spurred the transformation of eastern Lynnwood into a retail and office district.

column1: Prior to contact with American settlers
column2: the Snohomish tribe of Native Americans used the area of modern-day Lynnwood for summertime activities
column3: including hunting
column6: and root cultivation. The Snohomish were relocated to the Tulalip reservation
column8: after the signing of the Treaty of Point Elliott in 1855
column9: opening the area for American settlement.Brown's Bay
column11: and modern-day Meadowdale were surveyed by American loggers in 1859. Logging on Brown's Bay began in 1860
column12: and the first American settlers arrived in the 1880s. Scottish-born stonemason Duncan Hunter became the area's first white resident in 1889
column13: filing an 80-acre (32 ha) land claim on modern-day 36th Avenue Southwest after moving west from Wisconsin. The claim was inherited by Hunter's son Basil
column14: who lived on the property until his death in 1982; it was later turned into the city's Pioneer Park in the late 1980s. Hunter was joined to the east by a claim from William Morrice
column16: Scotland. Settlers from Pennsylvania homesteaded along Cedar Valley
column17: to the south of Hunter and Morrice
column18: and near Scriber Lake (named for Peter Schreiber) in 1888
column19: leading to the establishment of the area's first schoolhouse in 1895.

column2: the Lynnwood area was gradually logged by private companies and mill operators
column3: leaving behind plots with tree stumps. The arrival of the Seattle–Everett Interurban Railway in 1910 brought reliable transportation to the area
column4: as well as real estate speculators. The Puget Mill Company
column5: then the largest landowner in southern Snohomish County
column6: established the planned community of "Alderwood Manor" in 1917 and marketed the area to urban dwellers wishing to build farms in the countryside. Alderwood Manor
column8: gained streets named for tree species and was divided into 5-to-10-acre (2.0 to 4.0 ha) plots that sold for $200 per acre. A 30-acre (12 ha) "demonstration farm" was built to educate new residents on raising crops and chickens
column9: as well as market the Alderwood Manor plots to "Little Landers"
column10: a nickname for the new residents. Alderwood Manor grew to over 1
column13: and had electricity and telephone services to most of its residents.The Puget Mill Company leased out its demonstration farm in 1933 and ceased operations at Alderwood Manor later in the decade
column14: amid declining sales during the Great Depression. At the same time
column15: the opening of the Pacific Highway (modern-day Highway 99) in 1927 and the decline of Interurban service in the 1930s shifted the center of economic growth west near Scriber Lake. Seattle realtor Karl O'Brien filed a plat along Highway 99 at 196th Street Southwest in 1937
column16: naming the development "Lynnwood" after his wife Lynn. Nearby businesses adopted the name during the 1940s
column17: leading to the formal use of "Lynnwood" by the chamber of commerce in 1946
column18: instead of the suggested "West Alderwood".Lynnwood gained its first post office in 1948
column19: after a successful lobbying campaign by the Lynnwood Commercial Club to the federal Post Office Department. Throughout the early 1950s
column21: in part because of the lack of sewers and other municipal services. Local residents sought to be annexed into Edmonds
column22: but were denied and left to organize their own city. In 1956
column23: a committee to study incorporating Lynnwood as a city was formed
column24: proposing an area of 6.7 square miles (17 km2) and population of 10
column25: 744 for the new city. A petition to incorporate was signed by 600 voters and submitted early the following year
column26: proposing a 6-square-mile (16 km2) city; during the early months of 1958
column27: several property owners asked to be removed from the proposal over disinterest in the Lynnwood group. An incorporation measure was put before voters on the November 1958
column28: failing by a narrow margin of 890 to 848 votes.A second attempt at incorporation
column29: with a revised size of three square miles (7.8 km2) and population of 6
column31: was approved by a 2-to-1 margin on April 14
column32: 1959. The successful incorporation was credited in part to the movement of dilapidated homes and structures from the right of way of Interstate 5
column33: a freeway to be built through Alderwood Manor
column34: into the Lynnwood area at the behest of the county government. Realtor Jack Bennett was elected the city's first mayor
column35: and the city council first met on April 20. The city charter was approved by the county commissioners on April 23
column37: marking Lynnwood's official incorporation as a third-class city. Two years after incorporation
column38: the young city was mired in a legal dispute with neighboring Edmonds over the annexation of the Browns Bay area
column39: which was resolved in an out-of-court settlement.Lynnwood began offering municipal services in its first years
column43: and acquiring a water system from the Alderwood Water District. The city began building its 18-acre (7.3 ha) civic center complex in 1969
column44: shortly after the approval of a bond issue to finance the $1.5 million project (equivalent to $8.18 million in 2019 dollars). The civic center
column45: located at 44th Avenue West and 194th Street Southwest
column46: came after a decade in leased facilities scattered around the city center. The first buildings on the campus
column47: including the city hall and public library
column48: opened in 1971. Later expansions to the civic center added a police station
column50: and an indoor recreation center.The opening of Interstate 5 in 1965 moved the commercial center of Lynnwood east towards Alderwood Manor
column51: which culminated in the proposed construction of a large shopping center in 1968. The 130-acre (53 ha) shopping center
column52: named Alderwood Mall and developed by Allied Stores
column53: was put on hold during the local recession of the early 1970s and was later sold to shopping mall developer Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. in 1976. Alderwood Mall opened on October 4
column55: sparking a major retail and residential boom in the Lynnwood area in the early 1980s. The Swamp Creek Interchange at Interstate 5 and Interstate 405 was completed in 1984
column56: creating a new regional connection to Alderwood and Lynnwood from the Eastside region of King County.During the 1980s
column57: Lynnwood gained its first of several office parks
column58: housing high-tech companies expanding from the Eastside and the Canyon Park area of Bothell. Shopping areas developed around Alderwood Mall at the same time
column59: creating the county's largest retail center
column60: and new housing areas spread out from the city limits of Lynnwood. Despite the development boom of unincorporated areas surrounding Lynnwood
column61: growth within the city itself slowed in the late 1980s and 1990s
column62: attributed to few annexations and slow natural growth.

column1: Lynnwood began developing plans for a "city center" near the Alderwood Mall area in the 1980s. Like other post-war suburbs
column2: Lynnwood developed without a defined central business district and sought to consolidate cultural facilities and high-density development in a manner similar to Downtown Bellevue. In the late 1990s
column3: the Washington State Department of Transportation rebuilt several interchanges on Interstate 5 in Lynnwood
column4: including the construction of a full diamond interchange at 196th Street Southwest costing $80 million. The city opened a $31 million
column5: medium-sized convention center in 2005 to anchor the future city center. The City of Lynnwood formally adopted its City Center Subarea Plan in 2007
column6: outlining plans to re-develop a 300-acre (120 ha) area between Lynnwood Transit Center and Alderwood Mall into a central business district. Development of the city center began in 2015
column7: with the construction of two apartment buildings and a hotel located near the convention center.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city of Lynnwood has a total area of 7.86 square miles (20.36 km2)
column3: of which 7.84 square miles (20.31 km2) is land and 0.02 square miles (0.05 km2) is water. The city is in the southwestern part of Snohomish County in Western Washington
column4: and is considered part of the Seattle metropolitan area. It is at the junction of Interstate 5 and Interstate 405
column5: approximately 16 miles (26 km) north of Seattle
column6: 19 miles (31 km) northwest of Bellevue
column7: and 13 miles (21 km) south of Everett.Lynnwood's city limits are roughly defined to south by Mountlake Terrace at 212th Street Southwest and the Interurban Trail; to the west by Edmonds along 76th Avenue West and Olympic View Drive; to the north by the unincorporated Picnic Point-North Lynnwood area
column8: near 164th Street Southwest; and to the east and south by the unincorporated Alderwood Manor
column9: along State Route 525 and Interstate 5. The city's urban growth area (UGA) includes Alderwood Manor and part of North Lynnwood
column10: extending east to Locust Way and Mill Creek
column11: and north to the Mukilteo UGA at 148th Street Southwest.Lynnwood is situated 300 to 600 feet (91 to 183 m) on a plateau above Puget Sound
column12: which lies to the city's west
column13: and consists of several hills and valleys. The city has eighteen identified drainage basins
column14: most of which drain into Swamp Creek or Puget Sound via Lund's Gulch. Other natural features within Lynnwood include Scriber Lake and Hall Lake. One of the highest hills in the Seattle area is 649-foot (198 m) Lake Serene Hill
column15: near the lake of the same name. The city has extensive views of the Olympic Mountains to the west and the Cascade Mountains to the east.The main retail and commercial corridor of the city is the "Lynnwood Triangle"
column16: bordered to the east by Interstate 5
column17: to the south by Southwest 196th Street
column18: and to the west by 44th Avenue West. The "Triangle" area has been proposed as the site of a city center for Lynnwood since the 1980s
column19: including planning for a future light rail station and high-density development surrounding it.

column1: The Lynnwood Police Department has 70 officers and 38 support staff
column2: overseen by chief Tom Davis since his appointment to the position in August 2016. In 2015
column3: Lynnwood had 81 violent crimes and 2
column4: 162 property crimes reported to law enforcement. The city's violent crime rate was 220 per 100
column6: ranking below the national and state averages; the property crime rate of 5
column8: 000 people was significantly above the national and state averages. Lynnwood has a relatively low overall crime rate compared to cities of the same size in Washington state
column9: but ranks high for property crime
column10: particularly larceny attributed to the nearby Alderwood Mall. In an effort to curb traffic violations
column11: the city government installed twelve red light cameras and four school zone cameras that issue approximately 24
column12: 000 tickets per year and generate $19.2 million in annual revenue.The 2008 rape of a teenage woman in Lynnwood
column13: part of a serial rape case
column14: was the subject of "An Unbelievable Story of Rape"
column15: an article published by ProPublica and the Marshall Project and the winner of a Pulitzer Prize. It was adapted into the true crime miniseries Unbelievable for Netflix in 2019. Between 2008 and 2012
column16: Lynnwood police had labeled 21 percent of rape cases as "unfounded"
column17: five times the national average for similarly sized municipalities. The victim
column19: was initially dismissed by detectives with the Lynnwood police department before the assailant
column21: was charged and convicted for the rapes of five more women. The city government agreed to a $150
column22: 000 settlement in the victim's lawsuit in 2014 and later changed the police department's procedures on sexual assault investigations.

column1: Lynnwood is defined as a non-charter code city and operates under a mayor–council government
column2: with a full-time mayor and city council elected by residents. The mayor serves a four-year term
column3: with no term limits
column4: and is joined in the Executive Department by an Executive Assistant and Assistant City Administrator. Since her election in 2013
column5: Nicola Smith has been mayor of Lynnwood; she previously served as dean of Edmonds College
column6: but had no other political experience when she defeated incumbent mayor Don Gough.The Lynnwood city council is composed of seven residents who are elected in at-large
column7: non-partisan elections to four-year terms that are staggered every two years. The council also appoints a city manager to oversee city operations. The council's meetings are held twice per month in a chamber at Lynnwood's city hall. According to the Washington State Auditor
column8: Lynnwood's municipal government employs 373 people full-time and operates on a biennial budget of $197.5 million. The municipal government provides emergency services
column12: and the municipal court and jail.At the federal level
column13: Lynnwood has been part of Washington's 2nd congressional district since 2012
column14: represented by Democrat Rick Larsen. Prior to the 2012 redistricting in Washington
column15: Lynnwood was part of the 1st congressional district
column16: represented by Jay Inslee. At the state level
column17: the city has been part of the 32nd legislative district since 2012
column18: and is represented by senator Maralyn Chase
column19: and representatives Cindy Ryu and Ruth Kagi. Lynnwood is wholly part of the Snohomish County Council's 3rd district
column20: represented by former Lynnwood city councilwoman Stephanie Wright since her appointment in 2010.

column1: Public schools in Lynnwood are operated by the Edmonds School District
column2: which also serves the cities of Edmonds
column3: Mountlake Terrace
column4: and Woodway. The district had an enrollment of approximately 20
column6: of which 16 are located in or around Lynnwood. The Edmonds School District has three high schools located in the Lynnwood area: Lynnwood High School
column8: and Scriber Lake High School. The Lynnwood High School was originally located adjacent to Alderwood Mall
column9: but moved to a new campus a mile (1.6 km) east on North Road in northern Bothell.Lynnwood is also home to two post-secondary educational institutions. Edmonds College
column11: offers two-year degree programs and other services. It enrolls an average of 11
column12: 100 students per quarter. Central Washington University offers four-year bachelor's degrees in select programs at its Lynnwood campus
column13: which it has shared with Edmonds College since 1975.Lynnwood also has several private schools

column1: The city of Lynnwood has over 350 acres (140 ha) of open space in 19 community and neighborhood parks
column2: as well as 14 miles (23 km) of recreational trails. Part of the open space is set aside as natural conservation areas
column3: including Lund's Gulch and Scriber Creek. The city also has special recreational facilities
column6: sports fields
column8: and a senior center. Central Lynnwood has two major parks: the Scriber Lake nature reserve; and Wilcox Park
column9: the first park in the city
column10: established in 1962. The city government also organizes several regular community events
column11: including the annual Fair on 44th block party

column2: Lynnwood and southern Snohomish County were served by a weekly newspaper
column3: The Enterprise. The newspaper was acquired by The Everett Herald in 1996 and renamed to The Weekly Herald in 2011. The Weekly Herald published its final issue on August 29
column5: due to revenue issues. Lynnwood is also part of the Seattle–Tacoma media market
column6: and is served by Seattle-based media outlets including The Seattle Times; broadcast television stations KOMO-TV
column9: and KCPQ-TV; and various radio stations. Non-commercial radio station KSER was based in Lynnwood from 1991 to 1994
column10: when it moved to Everett.Lynnwood opened its municipal library in 1971
column11: contracting services to the regional Sno-Isle Libraries district. The library is the most-visited in the system
column12: which serves most of Snohomish and Island counties
column14: 000 annual visits as of 2012. Lynnwood residents voted in 2006 to be annexed into the Sno-Isle Libraries district
column15: also approving an expansion and modernization that took place in 2013.

column1: Lynnwood has one property listed on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP): Keeler's Korner
column2: an automobile service station built in 1927 on Highway 99 at 164th Street Southwest.The Alderwood Manor Heritage Association was formed in 1991 after the demolition of the oldest home in Alderwood Manor
column3: located east of Lynnwood city limits. The preservation group succeeded in saving other early 20th century homes that were slated for demolition during a highway expansion
column5: city-owned park. The $1.8 million Heritage Park
column6: opened in 2004
column9: originally built in 1919; a cottage built for the Alderwood Manor superintendent in 1917; and a restored Interurban trolley car.The city has two other buildings determined to be eligible for a NRHP listing: the Masonic Temple
column10: built in 1921; and a former schoolhouse built in 1917. Both buildings are located near the city center southwest of Alderwood Mall.

column1: Lynnwood is located at the northern junction of Interstate 5 and Interstate 405
column2: the two primary north–south freeways in the Seattle metropolitan area. Interstate 5 continues south to Downtown Seattle
column3: and north to Everett and Vancouver
column4: British Columbia; Interstate 405 continues south to Bellevue and the Eastside
column5: and north to Mukilteo as State Route 525. Lynnwood has two additional state highways: State Route 99
column6: running north to Everett and south to Seattle; and State Route 524
column7: connecting to Edmonds in the west as 196th Street Southwest.Public transportation in Lynnwood is provided by Community Transit
column8: which serves most of Snohomish County
column10: the regional system serving the entire metropolitan area. Most bus service in Lynnwood is concentrated at hubs
column13: and Edmonds College. Community Transit operates local routes
column14: including Swift bus rapid transit on State Route 99
column15: and peak-only commuter service to Downtown Seattle and the University of Washington. Sound Transit operates all-day express service from Lynnwood Transit Center and Ash Way Park and Ride to Downtown Seattle and Downtown Bellevue. In 2024
column16: Sound Transit will begin operating Link light rail service to Lynnwood Transit Center
column17: connecting it to Downtown Seattle and the Bellevue–Redmond area. Light rail service is planned to be extended north to Downtown Everett
column18: via Ash Way and Paine Field

column1: Electric power in Lynnwood is provided by the Snohomish County Public Utility District (PUD)
column2: a consumer-owned public utility that serves all of Snohomish County. Puget Sound Energy provides natural gas service to the city; Lynnwood is also the terminus of a minor gas pipeline operated by the Northwest Pipeline Company.The City of Lynnwood provides municipal tap water service
column3: sourced from Everett's Spada Lake Reservoir
column4: as well as sanitary sewer and wastewater treatment. The city's wastewater treatment plant treats 5 million gallons per day (19
column5: 000 m3) that is discharged into Puget Sound. The unincorporated areas surrounding Lynnwood to the north and east are served by the Alderwood Water District; the district also operates an artesian well in northern Lynnwood that has gained popularity for its quality. The city contracts with Republic Services and Waste Management for garbage
column6: recycling

column1: Lynnwood does not have any general hospitals
column2: but is located near the Edmonds branch of Swedish Medical Center
column3: formerly known as Stevens Hospital. The city has several community and specialty clinics operated by regional healthcare providers
column4: including the Community Health Center of Snohomish County
column6: and The Everett Clinic.
